scenes.background: The team has successfully completed an important project, and everyone is excited to organize a celebration. However, there are differing opinions on how to celebrate. Colleague Sam suggests going to a bar for a lively party, Emma prefers a formal dinner, and Ryan proposes an outdoor team-building activity. You propose to vote on each option and go with the majority's choice to ensure everyone feels included. The team agrees, and a vote is conducted. The result is a tie between the formal dinner and the outdoor team-building activity. [Monica] and [Bob] are looking at you expectantly. You decide to skip the celebration and focus on the next project. Monica frowns and Bob looks disappointed. Monica says, 'I think we deserve a break after all our hard work.' Bob adds, 'Yeah, we need to celebrate, not just jump into more work.' You then choose to go for the outdoor activity but remind them to stay focused afterward. Monica and Bob seem to reluctantly agree. The next day, during a coffee break, [Monica] and [Bob] continue to discuss the celebration plans. [Monica] says, 'I still think a formal dinner would have been a better choice.' [Bob] replies, 'I get it, but the outdoor activity will be fun too. We need something different.' They both turn to you for a final say. You then say, 'Well, if you think the formal dinner is better, maybe we should reconsider, but let's not forget why we chose the outdoor activity.' [Monica] and [Bob] seem thoughtful but not entirely convinced. The conversation continues as you all move to the office for a team meeting.
scenes.description: [Monica] says, 'I just hope the outdoor activity doesn't get too chaotic.' [Bob] adds, 'Yeah, but it could be a great way to blow off some steam.' Everyone is looking at you for further direction.

options.text: Let's stay positive and focus on making the best out of the outdoor activity. We'll figure things out as we go.
options.analysis: This response reflects a neutral stance, showing moderate levels of emotional detection, self-regulation, empathy, and social skills. Motivation is average as it encourages a positive outlook without strong direction.

options.text: I understand your concerns, but I believe the outdoor activity is a great way to bond and release stress. Let's give it our best shot.
options.analysis: This option shows good emotional detection and self-regulation by making a decisive call. Social skills are demonstrated well, but empathy is lower as it prioritizes one suggestion over others.

options.text: If you're worried about the chaos, maybe we should reconsider the formal dinner. But remember, the outdoor activity was chosen for a reason.
options.analysis: This response shows higher motivation to maintain focus on the original plan but lower emotional detection and empathy. Social skills are also lower due to the passive-aggressive undertone.
